value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">book told the story of <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#kart" key="Arthur (King)">Arthur</rs>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Then, the instinct to enact, to impersonate</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">what they <del>see</del> heard came into being. Even the King &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Queen must have their minstrels to give shape</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to this hidden instinct. The author was</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[special?]: <del>the</del> for he displayed his body: after,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">because, feeling himself an outcast, he used the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">outsiders 
            <choice>
              <sic>prvilge</sic>
              <corr>privilege</corr>
            </choice> <del>to</del> of irresponsible</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">mockery. Yet just as we isolate those who</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">say  what we are too proud to admit, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">minstrel was tolerated. Even the churchmen,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">aware that <del>the</del> other gods than his were</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">being worshipped, <del>mus</del> could not suppress the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">actor. <del>When he was no longer</del> If they could,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">they constrained the juggler & the dancer</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to put off their leaves & their bells & to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">robe themselves as the [pilgrimages?] in a miracle</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">play. But when the old <del>pl</del> <del>story</del> 
            <choice>
              <sic>relgios</sic>
              <corr>religious</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">story was stale, they <del>left</del> played in the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[courtyard? churchyard?], & at last set up their pageant in the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">market place.</l>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
            <l>The churchmen</l>
            <l>loathed him.</l>
          </add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs>, it is said, was <del>a</del> <del>with</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">among the audience at one of these old pageants.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>He noted</del></l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="block">
            <l>And after her came jolly June 
              <choice>
                <sic>arryed</sic>
                <corr>arrayed</corr>
              </choice></l>
            <l><del>arrayed</del> all in green leaves, as he a</l>
            <l>player were</l>
          </quote>
